text: â€Land der Berge, Land am Stromeâ€œ (, meaning "Land of the Mountains, Land by the River") is the national anthem of Austria. It became the country's national anthem in 1946. The music of the song was originally thought to be composed by Mozart, but nowadays, different composers disagree. The words of the song were written by Paula von PreradoviÄ‡. == History == Nineteen days before Mozart's his death on 5 December 1791, he composed his last complete work, the â€Freimaurerkantateâ€œ, to which the melody of the Austrian national anthem is sung. But nowadays, many people do not believe that Mozart composed the tune for â€Land der Berge, Land am Stromeâ€œ; instead, many people think that it was composed by Werke zweifelhafter Echtheit â€“ Band 3 Orchesterwerke und Lieder, vol. X/29/3, pp. xxxiii, xxxiv, Neue Mozart-Ausgabe or Paul Wranitzky., year 73 Before the Second World War, Austria's state anthem was â€Sei gesegnet ohne Endeâ€œ, set to the tune of Joseph Haydn's â€Gott erhalte Franz den Kaiserâ€œ, which was the state anthem of Austria-Hungary. The German national anthem â€Deutschlandliedâ€œ uses the same tune, but with different words. The Nazis also used that tune, so to avoid being associated with them, singing that song was banned for some time after the war. Thus, a new anthem was created. The words of the new anthem were written by Paula von PreradoviÄ‡, who was one of the few women to have written words for a national anthem. On 22 October 1946, the song became Austria's national anthem officially, but at the time, it did not have words. Her words were added shortly in February 1947. On 1 January 2012, parts of the words were changed to make the song more gender-neutral (in a similar manner to "O Canada" in 2018). ===Attempts at gender-neutral language=== Since the 1990s, there have been many times to change the words so that the anthem sound more gender-neutral. In 2005, Women's Minister Maria Rauch-Kallat of the Austrian People's Party (Ã–VP) did not like the words sons, fraternal and fatherland, so she demanded that these be changed. Austria's largest newspaper did not like this idea. In January 2010, a female pop singer named Christina StÃ¼rmer presented a pop version of the sont â€Heimat bist du groÃŸer SÃ¶hne und TÃ¶chterâ€œ ("You are home to great sons and daughters") as part of a campaign by the Austrian federal ministry of education. She was sued for copyright violations by the estate of Paula von PreradoviÄ‡, but she was later cleared by the Austrian Supreme Court of JusticeDecision "Bundeshymne II/Rock me Paula", Supreme Court of Justice (Austria) (4Ob171/10s, 15 December 2010) who called it "a mere modernisation" and allowed the version to stand. Since 1 January 2012, a few words in the anthem are different from before. The text and notes of the anthem were officially put into writing in the â€Bundesgesetz Ã¼ber die Bundeshymne der Republik Ã–sterreichâ€œ ().Bundesgesetzblatt I Nr. 127/2011, 27 December 2011 == Lyrics == === German original === Words of the song in GermanBundesgesetzblatt I Nr. 127/2011, 27 December 2011, text and melody (in German) Pronunciation of these words using the IPA Words of the song in English [lant dÉ ËˆbÉ›ÉÌ¯.gÉ™ lant am ËˆÊƒtrÉ”.mÉ™] [lant dÉ ËˆÉ›.kÉ lant dÉ ËˆdÉ”.mÉ™] [lant dÉ ËˆhÉ›.mÉ ËˆtÍ¡sÊ°ÊŠ.kÊŠnftÍ¡s.raÉªÌ¯Ã§] [ËˆhaÉªÌ¯.mat ËˆgrÉ”.sÉ ËˆtÊ°Å“x.tÉ ÊŠnt zÃ¸Ë.nÉ™] [fÉ”lk ËˆbÉ›g.na.dÉ™t fyËr das ËˆÊƒÃ¸Ë.nÉ™] ğ„† [ËˆfiËl.gÉ.yËm.tÉ™s ËˆÃ¸Ës.tÉ.raÉªÌ¯Ã§] ğ„‡ [haÉªÌ¯s ËˆuÉ±.feË.dÉ›t vÉªlt Ëˆum.striË.tnÌ©] [ËˆliËkst deËm ËˆeËÉÌ¯.taÉªÌ¯l dÊŠ ËˆiËn.mÉª.tnÌ©] [ËˆaÉªÌ¯.nÉ™m ËˆÊƒtar.knÌ© ËˆhÉ›ÉÌ¯.tÍ¡snÌ© ËˆglaÉªÌ¯Ã§] [hast zaÉªÌ¯t ËˆfryË.É™n ËˆaË.nÉ™n.ta.gÉ™n] [ËˆhoË.É›ÉÌ¯ ËˆzÉ›n.dÊŠÅ‹ last ËˆgÉ›.tra.gÉ™n] ğ„† [ËˆfiËl.gÉ™.pryËf.tÉ™s ËˆÃ¸Ë.stÉ.raÉªÌ¯Ã§] ğ„‡ [ËˆmÊŠ.tÉªÃ§ iËn diË ËˆnoÊÌ¯.É™n ËˆtÍ¡sÊ°aÉªÌ¯.tnÌ©] [fraÉªÌ¯ ÊŠnt ËˆgloÊÌ¯.bÉªÃ§ ziË ÊŠns ËˆÊƒraÉªÌ¯.tnÌ©] [Ëˆar.baÉªÌ¯tÍ¡s.froË ÊŠnt ËˆhÉ”f.nuËÅ‹s.raÉªÌ¯Ã§] [ËˆaÉªÌ¯.nÉªÃ§ las iËn ËˆjÊŠ.bÉ™l.kÃ¸Ë.rÉ™n] [ËˆfaË.tÉ.lant diËr ËˆtroÊÌ¯.É™ ËˆÊƒvÃ¸Ë.rÉ™n] ğ„† [ËˆfiËl.gÉ™.liËp.tÉ™s ËˆÃ¸Ë.stÉ.raÉªÌ¯Ã§] ğ„‡ Land of peaks, oh, land of rivers, Land of fields, oh, land of steeples Land of labors, future-bound! Home thou art to prodigious kin, Shining brighter than ever been ğ„† Austria, of high praise! ğ„‡ Bold if battered, ne'er torn nor tattered Stands thou strong midst Europe fettered For thee art pledges saith! Since days long past, verily thou hast Trials of heated temper pas't ğ„† Austria, of true faith. ğ„‡ Joyfully jaunting, future-bound, As one nation, safe and sound, In high spirits newly found! All together now, in jubilation To thee, we pledge with animation ğ„† Austria, dearly loved! ğ„‡ ===Slovene version=== The last stanza was also translated into the Slovene language for the Carinthian Slovenes. :Hrabro w nowie tschaÃŸ stopimo, :prosto, werno, glei, hodimo; :upa polnie, delawnie. :Bratzkie sbor priÃŸega hkratie, :domowinie swestobo datie. :Ljubljena nam Austria! ==Parody== The same evening after von PreradoviÄ‡ learned that the words she had written were chosen for the national anthem, her sons, Otto and , made a parody of them. Land of the peas, land of the beans, Land of the four zones of occupation, we sell thee on the black market! And up there over the Hermannskogel gladly the federal bird flutters. Much beloved Austria! According to media researcher , the first two lines were popular in the schools of Vienna in 1955.Land der Berge, Land am Strome von Peter Diem ==References== Category:National symbols of Austria Category:Austrian anthems
title: National anthem of Austria
